title.narrative: EBOLA VIRAL DISEASE (EVD) EMERGENCY PREPAREDNESS AND RESPONSE IN YEI RIVER STATE SOUTH SUDAN

description.narrative:
This proposal is a six months’ emergency preparedness and response to Ebola Viral Disease (EVD) in ten health facilities in four counties (Yei, Morobo, Lainya and Kajokeji) in Yei River State. The State and counties are selected due to proximity and with porous borders to the Democratic Republic of Congo where Ebola outbreak is currently reported. The project will cover from January to to June 2019. It will be implemented in collaboration with all partners including other Implementing Agencies operating in Yie, Rapid Response Teams in the State, the National and State Forces relevant Technical Working Groups (TWGs) established to coordinate and guide the national and state level EVD preparedness and response. AAHI proposes a budget of $250,000 to operationalize the Yei Isolation Unit (being constructed by WFP) establish ten holding sites to isolate suspected EVD cases until referral to the IU in Yei hospital risk communication (public awareness on EVD prevention and alert) and to conduct healthcare facility and community based surveillance activities aligned to the Boma Health Initiative.
Background: The Ebola Viral Disease (EVD) outbreak was declared on 1st August 2018 in Northern Kivu and Ituri provinces in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) and as of 19th December 2018, a total of 560 (512 confirmed and 48 probable) cases have been reported of whom 336 (288 confirmed and 48 probable) have succumbed to the disease (Case Fatality Rate of 60%). The northern Kivu region borders four other provinces in Congo as well as Uganda and Rwanda. This makes it rated as very high risky for South Sudan in terms of importation of EVD into the bordering countries. In Yei River state, border points like Jale/Afoji, Kaya, Birigo, Liwolo are major crossing points to/from Uganda while Angebi, Senema, Ukaba, and Bazi are crossing points to/from DRC. Moreover, Yei Airstrip is a point of entry and transit point for flights from both within South Sudan and neighboring countries. These porous borders have uncontrolled movement of people especially refugees, internally displaced persons, traders and business people that could lead to increased risk of EVD spread in the event of any case or contact with a patient. As such South Sudan is among Priority 1 countries along with Rwanda, Burundi and Uganda as per WHO risk assessments to be on alert and establish EVD preparedness response plan particularly areas along the borders with cross border movements arising mainly due to insecurity and displacement of people. The prioritization was done based on their capacity to manage EVD and Viral Haemorrhagic Fever (VHF) outbreaks, and their connections and proximity to the areas currently reporting EVD cases.
